Description: Hooked in rt corner of mouth by circle hook with 1' of leader and pigtail. Response pending
Get sighting info; captured 5/19 & brought to Oahu for assessment; ingested hook; surgery 5/20
Large hook in left corner of mouth; no follow-up 5/20
Seen attempting to haul out trailing 18" of leader from hook in cheek. 4/10 captured on Larsen's beach by Jamie Thompton & volunteers and hook removed. Had punctured left cheek.

Seen trailing ~20' of line from mouth; went in water with difficulty…line snagging. Captured 12/30 at White Plains and brought to IRC for assessment. Surgery to remove large ulua hook, slide rig, & wire leader from esophagus/stomach on 12/31. Successful recovery & released 2 weeks later
Reported by D.B. Dunlap; circle hook in left corner of mouth trailing ~1 ft of line; hook removed by NMFS response team (Henderson, Sullivan, Cahoon, Levine, Norris) 15 Sept.

Reported by fisherman to have hooked seal; said he 'set' the hook and 'fought' the seal for a while before cutting line; Kauai volunteers suspected ID = R4DD based on location and known area frequented by R4DD; R4DD captured, examined, & x-rayed 8/5 between Donkey Beach & Anahola with no sign of hook or injury. Considered confirmed hooking but ID uncertain. Note R4DD found dead on 8/21/14 but death unrelated to any hooking
Source: T. Wurth, J. Thompton, M. Olry

Description: Found dead in shallows (location ~20 mi n of Kailua Kona), trailing line from mouth. Flown to Oahu & necropsy performed 7/5. 'J' hook had perforated esophagus and part of rt lung, causing pneumothorax & acute death.
Sighted by diver resting in underwater cave with large hook in lip and trailing 3' of line. Seal seen on 4 July at Kipu Kai without any trailing line or hook.
Hooked in left mouth by circle hook. Seal penned, sedated, & hook removed by PIFSC/PIRO 2 July at Olowalu, Maui. Hook under tongue and around mandible.

Hooked in rt corner of mouth by circle hook with slide rig & trailing ~3' of monofilament. Reported to have difficulty hauling out because of trailing line. Hook removed 6/25 by PIFSC & PIRO response team
Small J-hook with attached monofilament snagged on lowe midbody; hook fell off during capture to flipper tag seal

Reported by fisherman to have taken bait/hook and he cut line loose. Seal captured June 11 and brought to IRC for exam/treatment. Hook had been swallowed and was in thoracic level of esophagus at level of pectoral flippers. Hook removed manually with seal under anesthesia (through oral cavity, no surgery). Seal released near Camp Erdman June 12

Seal seen taking bait and possibly getting hooked; B. Billand saw fisherman's pole bend way down, & seal leap out of water; line broke; fisherman reported using 'sardines' as bait, do not know if live or dead bait; Seal seen later with no evidence of hook or line; being observed. Considered non-hooking fishery interaction.

Seen by Billands with green monofilament and attached ball of line trailing from left side of mouth; could not see if internal hook. Seal agitated & unapproachable. Seen on 13 March without hook or line.
small damashi hook with ~2-3 ft of trailing line snagged in cranial to RFF. Hook gone by 3/3/2014.
Seen with circle hook in trailing edge of RRF, no line. Seen on 2/18 to have lost hook
Large circle hook in mouth with slide rig & trailing 6-7 ft of line. Two reports from general public; seal left beach before photos or intervention; Seal confirmed on 3/6/14 to have lost hook/line

Kaiwi' seen by DB attempting to haul out with monofilament line wrapped around head and body. Team went out to assess but no sign of animal. On Jan 3 seal sighted again at Rabbit Island; team of Wurth, Barbieri, & Sullivan deployed. They were able to remove ~20' of line, swivel, & pigtail rig, but could not remove hook because net was inoperable (lost pole). Unable to determine if hooked over mandible. Seal released without removing hook. Hook removed successfully 20 February.
Hooked in left upper lip/muzzle by small hook, trailing 6 inches of line. Seal seen next day without hook. No intervention
Small hook in right corner of mouth, no line evident. Sighted 23 November without hook, lost it without intervention
~200 ft of fishing line entangled around cell-hpone tag; freed self by 5 September
Note: Added 2/11/14; also listed in entanglement log

Description: Unconfirmed hooking, possible leader hanging from left side of mouth; examination next day no hook/line apparent

Public reported hook in rt side of mouth; Kauai volunteers responded & took pictures of seal raising head, but could not see hook. Approx 1 hr later seal had moved down the beach so original haulout area examined and large ulua hook found in sand. Considered hooking and self-release.
Small damashi hook with ~12 cm trailing line in lower lip; freed self by 19 June

Hooked outside left cheek at mandibular junction; reported by fisherman who tried to reel in to cut line short, but line broke; Of the gear that he was using, what was left with the seal is a 2 ½” circle hook (with the barbs); 5 ft of wire (consisting of 4’wire leader and 1’hook leader); and just a bit of line. Photo indicates hook should fall out but maintaining vigilance. Seal resighted 6/16 at Olowalu without hook.

Circle hook embedded in left cheek and trailing ~50 ft of monofilament line; on 5/11 ~20 ft of line cut off by volunteer team; on 5/12 line cut to eye of the hook while seal was sleeping, but hook not removed. Seal may be pregnant, so no immediate plans to remove hook, will monitor condition; update May 19 seal seen without hook
Three (3) small 'damashi' hooks in left lower lip, trailing ~30' of light monofilament line; hooks & line removed by M. Olry, J. Thomton
Circle hook in right side of mouth, trailing 1' of monofilament; point of hook over mandible and protruding through floor of mouth; captured & hook removed by M. Olry and team

Hooked in left side of mouth by circle hook; hook removed by Babrieri & Guerin 19 March; hook was in deep tissue surrounding the mandible and required substantial manipulation to remove. Seal also tagged & given antibiotics.

Seal sighted injury in left corner of mouth caused by a hook which fell out by itself. Injury was c-shaped laceration where shank of hook had probably irritated and opened an injury. Was also a puncture wound where point of a hook would be. Seal found dead from natural causes 10 March
Small 'damashi' hook in 'D' lobe of left rear flipper;
ingested damashi hook (in esohagus) and damashi in LFF; removed 13 Feb

Circle hook and trailing leader, hooked through tongue and into left cheek; Seal captured & taken to DLNR base yard in Lihue. Hook removed by A. Kaufman & Beth Doescher DVM on 2/5. Seal released same day.

Location: Kapaa Beach Park 1 m north of Mahukona, Hawaii
Description: Displaying symptoms of respiratory distress, captured for imaging, diagnoses, and possible treatment. X-rays showed circle hook in esophagus. Seal died during x-ray & imaging procedures. Necropsy revealed circle hook at midlevel of esophagus,& hook had perforated trachea. Considerable scarring & connective surrounding hook, and a large 'plug' of soft tissue was obstructing the trachea, which was the cause for respiratory distress.
Note: Assigned to 2012 for SAR based on input from M. Barbieri that hook had been present for at least 6 weeks and probably longer. Likely was August 21 Incident below.

Description: Speared in head by 3-prong spear ('hawaiian sling'). Head of spear across forehead, with one prong having penetretated through and through the skin & blubber, but no puncture to skull. Animal restrained at Rabbit Island and spear head removed by Barbieri, Sullivan, & Guerin. Shaft of spear on beach ~30 feet away and also retrieved. Seal released with no apparent debilitating effects.

Report called in to hotline by fisherman who said seal was tangled in his net, but freed itself as he was pulling the net in. Follow-up visit to area revealed lots of fishing activity and a report of a seal having 'nibbled' at a net; no seal sighted.
Inside gillnet; partially entangled around HFs at one point; freed self and net was removed

Reported with small damashi hook in left corner of mouth; on 12/4 NMFS staff hazed him to get look & photos of open mouth to assess for line going down throat; none seen and has been resighted healthy

Hook, slide rig, pigtail, wire leader, & main line; hooked in right cheek; Captured 11/17/12 @ Sunset Beach & brought to WA. Very poor condition, lethargic, emaciated, green with algae, & severe tongue infection from line/hook lacerations in tongue. Very likely unable to feed. Procedure 11/19/12 removed necrotic tongue tissue and sutured up lacerations; rehabilitated at WA; released at Turtle Bay 11/29/12
UNCONFIRMED report of seal with hook in mouth; not resighted
Found dead on beach with pigtail of slide rig in corner of mouth, hook ingested, and trailing ~40 feet of monofilament. Carcass code 3-4 (not recently dead); necropsy pending

Hooked in right 'armpit' by circle hook and trailing ~20' of line. Hauled up near AF seal and then near water, alert, so unable to intervene. 9/20 follow-up, same location, and length of trailing line now shortened to only ~4'. Animal went in water before intervention attempted. Sept. 24 animal seen to have lost the hook. Hook apparently tore out with some resultant tissue damage.
Trailing 6' of line from mouth; no hook sighted. Seal seen since (9/8 & other dates) with no notation of any line. See follow-up report on 1 February 2013: Probably same occurrence.
Note: See 1 February 2013 incident; animal died as result of hooking, but in following year

Description: Hooked in chest by circle hook; shank protruding; trailing some leader; Seal seen 8/4 without hook

Sighted by DB Dunlap to have line protruding from mouth. Seal inspected without capture near Lanai lookout by Wurth et al; 2 lines protruding from left mouth, but could not capture for examination; captured 5/29, sedated, and x-rayed. No line present and no ingested hook. Seal released 5/29

Seen with leader protruding from mouth; inspected under sedation and found to have swallowed hook; brought to WA and zoo for x-ray and treatment; hook removed surgically from base of esophagus; post-operative complications due to internal sutures separating and resultant peritonitis. Seal euthanized

Bobber and swivel protruding from mouth; hook and line likely ingested; seal lethargic and 'arching' behavior suggestive of ingested hook. Team flew to Kauai May 9 to assess; seal captured & brought to WA for further examination & treatment on 5/9; seal's head/neck movement restricted, large swelling evident on neck, seal coughed up blood. Seal sedated 5/10 and hook removed from seals deep throat, distal to epiglottis. Seal maintained at WA for treatment due to fluid in lungs resulting from entanglement. Instrumented and released 5/1912

Location: Crappy Cove, nr Sandy Beach, Oahu
Description: Sighted early in morning by volunteer with small, 'damashi' hook on external throat, trailing small monofilament line; Hook removed by Guerin, Sullivan, Wurth on 4/30, but trailing line went to another hook in deep throat or base of tongue; were unable to remove; also left eye bloodshot and swollen shut; report on weekend of personnel throwing rocks at seal at spitting cave. Recaptured 5/5 on Rabbit Island, transported to WA for x-ray; x-ray showed damashi hook in base of tongue; seal sedated and hooked removed; seal released same day 5/5 at Sandy Beach

Found dead with skull fracture; considered anthropogenic injury, not necessarily fishery mortality; transverse fracture along left mid zygomatic arch; fracture to rt frontal bone at dorsal anterior edge of the orbital opening; trauma most likely cause of death; code 3 carcass

Hooked in left lip by circle hook, trailing ~2' of line with swivel & pigtail; Sighted by tour operator on 3/8 & again on 3/9 by PIC team (Littlan, Guerin, Viezbiecke). Captured for hook removal 26 March Kuau, Maui (near Paia) by PIFSC & PIRO team, but unable to cut hook with bolt cutters to remove. Cut leader at hook and released seal, to hopefully shed hook. Seal seen as late as 9/22/12 still with hook. Updated on 2/8/13 seal sighted at Green Sand Beach, HI definitely without hook
Found dead by Kauai volunteers in morning; swivel and pigtail at edge of mouth, hook ingested; flown to Oahu for necropsy 6 March.
Hooked in left corner of mouth by small damashi rig trailing monofilament line. Hook removed by D. Schofield, NMFS
Call from airport security reporting line trailing from seal's mouth. Small circle hook in right side of mouth, with 2 feet of trailing line; removed by Guerin & Sullivan 1 Feb.
Ulua hook and leader in left corner of mouth; removed by Kauai volunteers
Hooked right corner of mouth, medium circle hook, pigtail, weight; removed by NMFS personnel 26 January, 2012
Found dead from gunshot wound; bullet found in carcass; not necessarily fishery interaction but included for the record.
Hooked on right side of mouth by large circle hook, trailing monofilament (unknown length). Seen & Photo'd swimming by B. Billand. May be pregnant. Resighted 12 January on Big Island without hook.

Location: Molokai, south shore between La'au Pt. and Hale o Lono Harbor
Description: Found dead with skull fracture; blunt force trauma; not necessarily fishery interaction but included for the record

Location: Molokai, south shore between La'au Pt. and Hale o Lono Harbor
Description: Found dead with skull fracture; blunt force trauma; not necessarily fishery interaction but included for the record. Large 'out of environment' rock found next to carcass on beach
Monofilament line wrapped around neck and through mouth; line fresh; line removed by NMFS personnel; reclassified from debris entanglement to fishery interaction by JH 3/1/12
Medium sized circle hook in left corner of mouth, no line trailing; hook removed 13 sept by Wurth, Sullivan, Guerin--Kaena Pt.
Large circle hook trailing ~1' of monofilament in left corner of mouth with barb protruding from skin; 9/19 report from B. Billand that RW08 sighted at Maile Pt. without hook.

Hooked in ventrum, ~8" anterior to penile opening, by small treble hook and trailing ~3" of lightweight monofilament line; one unsuccessful attempt by volunteer to pull hook out by tugging on line. On 1 Sept. seal observed again, with hook still present but no line trailing. No swelling or signs of infection. Seen 9/7 to have lost hook without intervention.
Source: T. Wurth and M. Bane; M. Olry

Description: Unconfirmed; call from bystander said animal had 3' of 100-200 lb test line trailing from mouth and 'coughing'. No resight, no confirmation

Snorkeler reported adult, tagged seal swam by him and his daughter, and seal had fishing line wrapped around body, and a 'large ulua hook' in its side. Snorkeler cut line and pulled hook out. Level A form completed by Mimi Olry
Hooked in left corner of mouth by cmall 1" circle hook with attached leader, lead weight, swivel, and pigtail. Hook removed later that day at Campbell Industrial Park by PIFSC personnel

Hooked through left lower lip by rusting circle hook, trailing ~6' of wire leader. Resighted ~16 June at Kaena Pt. by Scott Ashlock who took pictures. Hook documented as having come out by itself on 7/9
Hooked in left corner of mouth by large circle hook with attached swivel, leader, & pigtail--Slide rig. Seen on Molokai end of December, 2011 without hook.
large and deep laceration left posterior…possible prop wound?
Hooked by circle hook in left corner of mouth, no line visible; seal sighted at Rabbit Island on 2/14 and 2/19 without hook

Call at 6:20 PM from person witnessing men dragging net ashore with entangled seal; seal disentangled and carried back to water by 4-5 men, and seal did not appear to be moving. HPD responded shortly thereafter and saw nothing (may have been at wrong location). DOCARE interviewed witnesses later in evening who were positive it was a seal in net. Nov 15 DOCARE scanning area in boat looking for more. No carcass ever found, so no confirmed mortality, but entanglement considered confirmed. Considered false alarm and not included in Gobush table.

Photographed with small hook and monofilament leader trailing from back, hooked in dorsum just posterior to transmitter unit. Hook removed by PSD & PIRO personnel 30 Sept. Very small circle hook with ~6 inches of lighweight monofilament
Seen/photographed with hook and ~12' of trailing line. Hooked through skin on LFF, dorsal side. Seen again 11 September to have lost hook unaided.
Photographed with ~6" of steel leader and attached pigtail coming out of mouth. Seal tagged on 25 August, no hook or line present, nor was there any injury to indicate previous presence of a hook.

Observed/photo'd by Eric Tong. Large circle ulua hook in left cheek, tip protruding through skin, trailing ~8 inches of heavy monofilament. Resighted with hook 17 August. Status the same…monofilament has pigtail attached to end. Seal seen on 6 September without hook, came out byitself.

Lightweight fishing line tangled around instrument on animal's back, and trailing hook with fish (not sure if bait or catch); line cut loose by D. Schofield without restraint (assisted by B. Becker, J. Henderson, M. Cahoon, D. Look, R. Billand, B. Billand)

Hooknet: Floater, with possible line and hook
Description: Fisherman reported 8' seal seen swimming, trailing an orange fishing floater 6" - 8" behind mouth. Floater was swinging across seal's head, hitting behind the eyes as seal swam. Fisherman did not see any line or hook. Presumption that floater was trailing from a line hooked on seal somewhere. Nicole Davis responded, search was made for seal, but seal so hooked was ever resighted.
Fishing line wrapped around head and front flippers. Seal freed self (?)
Seal died of multiple skull fractures due to blunt force trauma; source unknown

Seen swimming offshore by boat captain with hook & trailing 1 foot of monofilament line. Hook removed by M. Olry & volunteer team 28 April. Circle hook with slide rig & pigtail. Hooked in skin ventral to mouth (not in mouth).
Found offshore entangled in monofilament gillnet, drowned
3 - gaping wound/laceration R posterior at RHF; Likley propeller wound
Seen with hook in mouth. Hook removed April 2 by Olry, assistant, Guerin, Ko
J' hook with wire leader attached to pigtail & swivel. Hooked in left lower lip. Hook removed by NOAA personnel same day (14 March)

Fisherman reported seal hooked in mouth by ulua circle hook. Fisherman reeled in and line broke, trailing 2-3 feet. Seal later seen on nearby beach with line from mouth. Seal sighted 13 March at Mokuleia, Oahu without hook. Volunteers hazed seal to inspect open mouth. No hook.

Report and photos of seal interacting with shorefisherman; report from observer said seal 'snagged' during fishing. Follow-up 1 March by PIFSC personnel (Wurth, Guerin, Farry) to place cell phone tag did not reveal any evidence of seal having been hooked. May have just been taking bait during observed interaction on 21 Feb. TW & JH decided 2-9-15 that 'snagged' meant hooking.
Superficial hookings above right eye, in left muzzle, and right rear flipper; removed by PIFSC & PIRO personnel 17 February
Hooked in left cheek by large circle hook. Hook removed by PIFSC & PIRO personnel 17 February
2 small hooks, superficial; one on LFF trailing ~2 ft of line; one near penile opening; has not been sighted since 13 February
Circular burn wound on right side of chest; some campfires remnants nearby leads to conclusion that somebody had prodded seal with a hot stick

Location: Offshore of Moanui Beach (Mile Marker 19.5) Molokai (east side)
Description: Found dead by fisherman; necropsy revealed animal had been shot in head. No evidence of fishery interaction, included in this file for the record.

Plastic 'squid' lure with treble hook, hooked through pelage on left lower neck; hook removed by T. Wurth, C. Yoshinaga, D. Schofield on 3 Oct. Was seen on 1 Oct without hook, so became hooked sometime 1-2 October

Seen by onlooker at Punaluu boat ramp with 'large ahi' hook stuck in right side of its neck. Confirming photo from Justin V. Aug 11. Photo shows circle hook embedded in neck. No trailing line. Seal seen on October 13 by J. Viezbicke to have lost hook.

Seen with rusting hook at Rabbit Island, and subsequently at Kaena Pt., Oahu. Photos show hook in lower jaw trailing 6" of wire leader & swivel. Resighted several times but never in location suitable for restraint. Sighted on 9/18/09 and seen to have lost the hook.

Seen with small hook and trailing lightweight line from left side of mouth. Response team found the seal on 22 July without hook. Restrained animal to tag him and examined mouth; found no sign of damage.

Seen trailing line from left side of mouth, both at Irma's beach as well as underwater at spitting cave. Hook never sighted. When next sighted on 19 July did not have any hook or line. T. Wurth inspected more closely on 20 July and saw nothing.

Seen trailing line & swivel 15 June, no hook visible; captured 20 June and hook too deep in throat for manual removal. Brought to Oahu, x-rayed, hook in deep throat. Anaesthetized & hook removed 23 June. Circle hook with monofilament, swivel & pigtail. To be returned to Kohala area 25 June, 2009
Note: Yes, non-serious for SAR due to mitigation

Description: Seen with hook & trailing line by NPS personnel, who restrained animal, but hook too deep to remove, so cut away line. NMFS response team (Levine, Wurth, Yoshinaga) removed hook on 27 May. Hooked deeply in base of tongue with only shank visible. Circle hook with pigtail and monofilament leader.
Note: Yes, non-serious for SAR due to mitigation

Description: seal killed by gunshot. No indication of fishery interaction, but included in this file for the record
Seen swimming off Makai Pier, Oahu with hook in left side of mouth, side of face swollen. Hook removed by NMFS and volunteer personnel 3 May at Kalaeloa Beach, Oahu.
Note: Yes, non-serious for SAR due to mitigation

Description: Seal found dead. Necropsy 20 April indicated cause of death consistent with gunshot to head. No indication of fishery interaction, but included in this file for the record

Photos show rusted hook in right corner of mouth trailing line. Hook removed by NMFS team on 22 April at Yokohama Bay, Oahu. 6.0 circle hook trailing 18" of monofilament line, with swivel and pigtail. Hook in lip.

Photo found by DB Dunlap on Flickr website, taken by C. Cross on 3/25/09. Picture shows hook in lower lip, shaft, wire leader, and swivel visible. Hook removed at Manana Island 30 March by NMFS personnel.

Observed by D.B. Dunlap using scope from Makai Pier. March 3 hook removed by Henderson, Levine, & Littnan. Large circle hook with slide rig pigtail & 6" wire leader. Seal deeply hooked in base of chin (externally, through pelage, not in mouth) with tip deeply lodged in musculature.

Hooked in left corner of mouth by small circle (papio) hook. Hooking event sighted, and fisherman reeled in as far as could, but cut line, leaving 150' trailing. Line became tangled on rocks. Mimi Olry responded and cut line, freeing seal still trailing ~5 ft of line, and later (2/8) caught animal and removed hook and all remaining line. Considered 'serious' for fisheries because animal trapped to reef/rocks by line but non-serious for SAR because mitigated
Note: Yes, non-serious for SAR due to mitigation

Description: Sighted with heavy monofilament line with frayed end coming out of mouth. No hook, swivel, or other rig observed. Possible ingestion of hook or rig. Intervention considered but pending based upon regular observations of seal. Sighted on Oct 27 and 29 without line or hook and seal acting normally. Update being resighted in 2013 so non-serious for SAR
Note: Yes, non-serious for SAR due to mitigation 9 hookings 2008

Description: Hook and trailing pigtail, swivel, & weight in left corner of mouth; Hook removed by S. Farry, and 3 volunteers on 5 September; Hook was around ramus of mandible.
Note: Yes, non-serious for SAR due to mitigation

Description: Sighted with 2" 'ulua hook' in left side of mouth, trailing 1' of line. Situation pending; Update as of 21 Sept. had been resighted but not viewed sufficiently to ascertain hook status. Good observations on Sept 25 and no hook visible.
Small hook with ~1" of line in left hip/pelvic area; No action taken, non-serious and from photos hook deemed likely to come out without assistance to animal. Seen on July 27 without hook.
Hooked in right corner of mouth, in lip, by small circle hook with eel bait, trailing 10-12 ft of line. Hook removed same day by Tracy Wurth, Bob Braun.

Seen with line coming out of mouth; seal captured and instrumented 6/14; Seal captured on June 15 to remove hook, but hook not visible; barrel swivel & pigtail visible at edge of mouth. Considerable strain/pulling on line during capture, but gear did not come out. Satellite tagged for future recapture. Seal recaptured on June 24 at Nomilo, Kauai and brought to Oahu, but no hook or line visible, presumed to have swallowed gear. Endoscope, x-ray, and ultrasound at MCBH on June 27 revealed no internal gear, so seal must have passed or regurgitated whatever it swallowed. Seal released June 29, 2008 at Kauai. No hook was ever seen.recaptured and brought to Oahu for surgery 6/24 though no hook/line visible; surgery showed no ingested hook
Preliminary report 5/30. Small, grayish seal seen trailing line, swivel, & wire leader from mouth. ; No photos or info, could be R4DP (above)

Hooked in lower lip and around mandible by circle hook, trailing swivel and line. Line cut off by public on May 3, leaving ~1ft of line/hook still in seal. NMFS responded May 4. Hook removed by S. Farry, M. Olry et al. Photos available.
Note: Yes, non-serious for SAR due to mitigation

Description: Hooked in back by treble hooks of a 'popper' lure, commonly used in shorecasting. Response personnel (M. Olry et al) cut line but left lure in place, since they didn't have staff/sedation to restrain adult male. Shallow hooking through skin of dorsum, so consensus was that lure would fall out by itself. Seen May 4 to have lost the lure. Photos available
Small circle hook in left corner of mouth, trailing 6" of line. No intervention; seen 5 May with hook still present. Seen at Wailua 29 July to have lost hook

Loop of monofilament with trailing monofilament, tightly wrapped around lower jaw, causing indentation into sides of jaw. Seal restrained (26 Sept.) by Eric Brown & Tracy Wurth. Tracy cut monofilament & pulled off. No hook evident. Line old, and incident classified as a debris entanglement.

Hook seen by Eric Brown. Hook in right upper lip with trailing line, trailing line loosely wrapped around head & neck. Hook removed 8 August by Jason Baker, Chad Yoshinaga, Bob Braun, Eric Brown, & Randall Watanuki. Several feet of trailing line. Hook had punctured through upper right lip and trailing several feet of line. During capture hook was dislodged from seal, line clipped & pulled through. Tracy will send photos.
UNCONFIRMED Report by third party to Eric Brown that seal was hooked in the head. No hard evidence found, but photo taken on 13 July shows this seal with a new scar on forehead.

Reported to Mimi Olry to have hook in right side of face not in mouth with ~3 feet of trailing line; Removed same day by Mimi & volunteers. Removed 1" diameter circle ulua hook with 8 feet of trailing line attached. De-hooking documented on YouTube. Tracy will send photos

Seen hooked by health service nurse Julie Sigler. Hook in mouth. Hook removed following day by NPS personnel Randall Watanuki and Eric Brown; barbed hook trailing some line had gone through mouth and had punctured the cheek. Hook and line lost in sand and not retrieved. Have pictures.

UNCONFIRMED report by third party, to Randall Watanuki (NPS) that this seal was hooked in the lip. Brenda Becker tagged another seal on 6/28, looked at RB06 and no hook was present, and no conclusive wound was evident (only a slight moist/reddish area in middle of lower lip). Also, another weaner, RB02, was DEFINITELY hooked (see incident above) around the same time. So it is possible that the third party saw RB02, not RB06.

Location: Lapakahi State Park, near Kawaihae, Hawaii
Description: Hooked in left cheek by large, slide bait hook trailing unknown amount of line. June 7, 2007, J. Viezbiecke approached seal to check on hook, and seal moved and hook came out by itself. Was a BARBLESS circle ulua hook.

Seal_Size_Sex_ID: Adult Female tag 5AA Perm ID RK13
Description: Bystander reported seeing shorefisherman with seal on line and then cut line. Bystander snorkeled out to see seal swimming, trailing ~100' of monofilament line from mouth and appeared to be gagging, but could not see hook. Seal may have been hooked on opposite side of mouth, or may have swallowed hook. Update on June 2, seal seen without hook.
Tangled and drowned in nearshore gillnet. Necropsy conducted 29 May. Some reports that a second seal was also entangled (second seal definitely present at scene), but escaped.
Accidental skull fracture during capture for instrumentation; seal died; non-fishery interaction

Small 'J' hook with 1' of light line, hooked in right rear flipper, medial webbing, with attached homemade fly or lure (pictures available); "damashi" rig characteristic of whipping for akule or other small fish; Seal restrained on April 10 for instrumentation and seen to have lost hook
Found entangled and dead in gill net off Makai Pier, Waimanalo, Oahu by diver on 15 October. Carcassed recovered by DOCARE, PIFSC, & PIRO personnel on 16 October.

First sighted with hook on 15 September by fishermen, but hook not removed until 27 October by M. Olry, D. Thornberg, N. Monasevitch, K. Ornalles, and Garrett (no last name). Circle hook with ~8" nylon coated wire leader. Hooked in right side of mouth; wound described as minimal, but some infection evident.
Same seal as incident below (hooking #46). Captured and ulua circle hook & slide rig leader removed from corner of mouth by M. Olry et al.

Reported hooked by fishermen to have cut seal free from hook/gear. Seal captured later in day by M. Olry et al and examined. No hook found but recent small wound in mouth where hook had been. Released.

Surfer called in report to seal sighting line; 3" hook in chest of seal, barb protruding, had hooked about 1" of flesh. Trailing a little line; seal on beach but later had left before PIFSC personnel could confirm
Ulua hook and slide bait rig, hooked in right corner of mouth. Hook removed by Mimi Olry, Don Heacock, & volunteers.

Scuba diver sighted seal swimming with hook & trailing line/bleach bottle; diver approached (in boat) and was able to soft gaff the bottle/line and cut it ~2 ft from seal; more details forthcoming (1/4/06)
Report from Gobush table found 12 Aug 2014; net with float wrapped around mouth

small 'J' hook with 1' of light line, hooked in right cheek (outside mouth), with attached homemade fly or lure (pictures available); "damashi" rig characteristic of whipping for akule or other small fish; Seal seen on 29 December, 2005 to have lost hook without intervention
Sighted with hook and 8" line in left corner of mouth. Decision made to leave her alone as she's probably pregnant. On 9/6/2005 sighted without hook, slight blood smear at left corner of mouth.
Photo with hook & trailing line on 8/17/05; Hooked in corner of mouth, appears non-serious; hook removed by Mimi Olry & volunteers August 20; Line heavy as for targeting ulua, but no slide rig
Report to Mimi Olry, DLNR, Kauai of hooked seal. Hook removed by JRH, RB, MO, & volunteer on 8/13/05, PMRF, Kauai; circle hook, no gear or line. Hooked in corner of mouth, outside jaw
Source: PIRO stranding summary July, 2005; JH presence

Description: Large, probably molting, seal reported by bystanders hauled out on rocks with bright green line trailing from mouth. Bystander cut line to about 1/2 seal body length (~3'). Bob Braun spoke with bystanders to get complete story. Hook never sighted. Seal not resighted with line.

Seal observed by contract painter at Germaine's Luau; seal thrashing in water and apparently entangled in net; R. Braun went to site and found no seal, but fishermen pulling in the net. Net had large hole in it where seal had apparently become entangled and freed itself. Net had been set the previous night.
Divers observed animal with line trailing from mouth. Animal was hooked and fisherman had cut line to free animal. No subsequent resightings
Initial report on 26 or 27 July; Bob, Braun, Brad Ryon & Don Heacock removed 3.5 inch circle hook, leader, swivel, & pigtail on 31 July; hook in lower jaw muscle (buccal pouch) outside of ramus.

Unconfirmed but reliable report by Camp Erdman counselor of seal with hook in lip; seal started to haul out at night, but then continued towards Kaena Pt. and counselor stopped following after a while (was at night).
Seal sighted by S. Farry & B. Ryon with ulua hook in mouth; capture attempt failed 9 June; seal later observed to have lost hook; lip hooking, non-serious injury
Probable sighting 4 June, definite sighting 7 June Kapaa; seal eventually captured and brought to Oahu for surgery to remove hook; successful surgery on June 17; serious injury

Seal tangled in nearshore gillnet and cut loose by two fisherman. Point of entanglement was a monofilament leader which was trailing from a hook in the seals' lip (see incident below); fisherman cut leader with approximately 1 foot of line remaining, as well as part of net. Later in day seal captured and hook removed by Braun, Littnan, and Farry.
Seal hooked in lip by hook, which was still baited with squid. Hook then caused seal to become entangled in gillnet (see above for details)

Multiple reports corroborate incident of fishing for kawakawa using opelu for bait from pier; large seal hooked in mouth (one report said 'lip') for some time (up to 30 minutes) while fisherman attempted to retrieve as much line as possible before cutting loose.
Call to Kauai contractor that a seal was hooked by fisherman slide rig fishing with tako; fisherman cut line when he realized he'd hooked a seal; second-hand report
Seal hooked in back of mouth, outside mandible; fisherman pulled in and cut main line; hook removed by PIRO personnel on Aug 1, 2003; non-serious injury
Seal stole bait from ulua slide rig fisherman without becoming hooked, fishery interaction only; Immediately theraafter animal became hooked by adjacent companion fisherman (see hooking #29 above)

Seen swimming by Poipu on July 3 with hook, slide rig, and trailing line. Part of line cut off on July 8 by Gretchen Johnson at Sheraton Beach. Seal likely to be victim sighted on 22 July at Mahaulepu without hook. Probably hook came out by itself

Hooked in back corner of right side of mouth. Hook small & containing small part of lightweight monofilament leader. K. Kawamoto said looks like part of recreational sabiki rig, used by shorecasters. Hook removed by MMRP & PIRO personnel.
Hooked in lower right lip, with trailing steel leader. Removed by MMRP personnel
Hooked through neck, with barb of hook protruding. Trailing 10-15 ft of monofilament line

Recrecreational diver reported he & colleagues disentangling seal, 4' - 5' long, and turtle from net. Approx 70 yds from shore, 20' of water; seal had been able to drag net to surface to breathe, then sunk back down to depth. Entangled about front and rear flippers
Son of RS00 (see below). Captured, hook removed, and released by NMFS & G Levine
photographed with small hook, trailing line, in back; later observed to have lost hook
hook in abdomen or front flipper, not resighted or removed.
Hook removed by DLNR personnel. Was in lower lip and base of jaw.
NMFS captured and removed hook.
NMFS response included capture and physical exam of seal. No hooks or line present, but slight injury was documented by veterinarian

Hooknet:
Observers said
it was a #7 or #9 ulua hook
Description: NMFS response included capture and physical exam, No hook was found, but some minor trauma was observed in mouth where hook had been present
Source:
CY and M. Shaw were NMFS res-
ponders

Description: Pup that was born and weaned at Kaneohe Marnine Corps Base was sighted with hook in right cheek; hook removed by bystander.
Seal hooked during a fishing tournament. Cut loose, but probably with ulua hook in mouth or jaw. No marks or tags reported
Seal captured for instrument attachment. Fish hook removed from mouth. See Kurt Kawamoto for type.

Location:
Maui (beach unknown) original observation. Hook removed at Ala Moana
 Beach Park
Description: Adult male removed from Laysan in 1994. First reports from Skippy Hau on Maui for 1-2 weeks, then seal showed up on Oahu. Ulua hook embedded loosely in lower right mandible. Seal captured, hook removed, and seal released. Observed again on north shore of Oahu
Hooking mortality, seal found with fish hook stuck in esophagus. Necropsy suggested death consistent with drowning. See necropsy report in interaction log.

Bottomfish fishery F/V Kaimi Kai No-Name Bank (north of FFS) Seal was an adult, which Chris had seen before at No-Name Bank, taking catch. Animal had scar on the back (which suggests female). Had taken the catch (probably uku) and the hook was lodged
Source: Report via email JRH: Name: Chris Jansson. Contact Al Katekaru for more info.

Description: Found entangled and dead in gill net off "Pray for sex" beach. The history and pulmonary state of the animal were consistent with drowning as a cause of death.
Pregnant (and then nursing) adult female observed with hook and ca. 40cm leader line in mouth. Hook stock about 4-5cm. Hook unknown
A monk seal had been observed near the Hyatt (Shipwreck Beach) with a large hook in its mouth and trailing about 6-7 feet of 45 lb. monofilament line. Longline? (see below)

Received a copy of a longline log that indicated that a monk seal had been taken and released uninjured. May be the same seal as reported above. (JH note, unlikely to be same, date of interaction on log was Feb 24, 1994)
Source:
Gene Nitta (see
copy of email in
 interaction
 notebook

Description: See notes in interactions notebook - Don Heacock reported a seal with a large hook in its lower jaw. The seal was hauled out a Kipu Kai Ranch on Kauai, and was reported to Don by Mr. Brain Cairis, manager of the ranch. Don described the hook on the telephone as a longline hook, but in his written report called it a large "ulua" hook. Said the hook was slightly rusty and trailing about 3/4 m of (estimated) 100 lb. monofilament line with a swivel at the end. The seal was confirmed in a later sighting (based on scars) to be adult male. Don saw the seal again on 22 November and the hook was no longer present.
...related that ... told her they were feeding kahala to 6 -7 seals following their boat. They were near to 66 fathom bank at the time.
Fish hook in right side of mouth. Seal had been hooked within the previous 10 hours. Hook was removed with help of Coast Guard personnel. Recreational?

Area affected: lower left side of neck, ventral Description: 3 injuries were observed in the same area. Two were approx. linear and parallel to each other. Both were at least to the fat layer maybe even to the muscle layer in some areas. The other one w
Fish hook in lower lip. Hook rusty and probably of local origin (not longline). Seal YU48 seen 6 days later without hook. Recreational?

Injury #'s 3 and 5 involved longline hooks. Three seals with hook in mouth or line protruding from mouth. Injury 2 was a mangled jaw plus other clean lacerations. Injuries 4*, 6*, 7*, 11, 12, 16*, 17, 20, 21, 23, 29*, 30*, 33*, 39*, 88*, 93, 114*, 123*
Observed head injuries that were not characteristic of wounds normally observed on monk seals. No actions taken.

Possible (not "probable") injuries other than those BLB and LMH describe above, are #'s 01- left eye, 28- left eye, 42- left eye. I am not at all sure of the origin of the injuries or how characteristic these are. They are relatively rare but...

Inj. #s 00, 03, 06, 07, 08, 09, 10, 15, 34, 79, 85, all considered probable propeller
cuts. Injury # 21 is also suspect- a severely broken lower jaw. This subadult male also had "mating" lacerations on its dorsum and both sides. See 88-89 FFS report.
WGG removed a large "ulua" or bottomfish hook from seal.

Anecdotal report...that half the bottomfishing vessels (that is about 5 of 10 - I think anecdotal rather than exact) feed monk seals bait fish on one side of their boat while bringing in fish on the other side. She was also told that fishermen feed seals kahala (rainbow runners), fish considered to ciguatera toxic for human consumption. ... says that seals have come up to the whaler (where in the atoll ?) very curious.

In 1989, --- explained that lobster fishing boats revealed to him that seals were following their boats and eating discarded cephalothoraces. He told me this when I described the series of "prop cuts" I mention above. In addition, coincidentally, there In 1989, --- explained that lobster fishing boats revealed to him that seals were following their boats and eating discarded cephalothoraces. He told me this when I described the series of "prop cuts" I mention above. In addition, coincidentally, there was a lobster boat in the vicinity of FFS during the beginning of April when 6 of the presumed injuries occurred.
Seal at Necker I. found dead, entangled in rope bridle over lobster trap actively fishing.

Fishhook and attached monofilament line caught in mouth of pup (after release from HS pen). Swam into water before staff could get there to release hook. Later that day found with hook out of mouth but in chest. Seal restrained and hook removed. See Reddy & Griffith 1988 for details (note figure captions in this publication are reversed) - Recreational?
Seal found with fishhook in lower lip. Hook later came out by itself. Photo in photo files. Hook from bottomfish fishery. Reported by Ittner, documented in JRH 1985 entanglement summary.

1976 memo by John Naughton to Regional Director specifically refers to monk seal drowned in nearshore gillnet off Kauai in March, 1976. Incident recalled/added in 2003. John N. has no field notes on incident, but remembers it.

See Bob Humphrey's account of fisheries interactions observed from Cromwell.
 (Have copy in interaction notebook)
